span.span: COVID-19 Impact on Tom’s Service
by Taylor Compton

During the Coronavirus outbreak, multiple businesses have been affected including Tom’s Service. The outbreak leads Tom’s Service to lose a helper, take better caution on things they use every day, and become more organized.

Ever since the Coronavirus outbreak, businesses have been told to take better caution, shut down, or even change their ways on how their business runs. Luckily Tom’s Service is considered an essential business, so they can stay open.

Tom Meier, the owner of Tom’s Service, says that they are still fixing cars, and they still have been staying busy. But one of the helpers did take off just to be safe and not take the risk of bringing it home to his family.

In Nebraska, there have been quite a few beautiful days lately, and a lot more people have been going fishing. Fishing licenses, minnows, and park permit sales have gone up along with alcohol sales. Meier says, “Nebraska is too beautiful to stay inside, you have to go outside eventually.”

One thing that Meier also realizes is that the Coronavirus has changed the outlook on stuff that we use every day. Meier heard a quote that says, “Tough times are here, and they’re coming, but tough people get through it.” Meier also has to make sure that he keeps himself organized so he can order parts in a timely manner. The place where he gets his parts is in the same situation where they can only deliver parts on a certain day.
Meier sums it all up by saying, “It’s not business as usual, but we are trying to adapt to whatever it is going to take.”
COVID-19 Impact on Elementary Children
by Samantha Fischer

As COVID-19, Coronavirus, quickly started taking over the country, and everyone has been giving their attention to elders or people with underlying health conditions. COVID-19 might not physically disturb children, but mentally, the children are going through a lot.
Pierce Elementary 6th grader, Jackson Fischer says, “I miss being around my friends and P.E. It’s a little bit harder for me to do homework too.”

Elementary school is where young children learn how to read, write, and go through the basic learning blocks of life, and while the school has given them work to do at home, it’s still not the same as having a one on one learning experience at school.

According to COVID-19 Educational Disruptions and Responses by UNESCO, “These nationwide closures are impacting over 91% of the world’s student population. Several other countries have implemented localized closures impacting millions of additional learners.”

Not only do students not get to learn in school, but they also lose the ability to see their friends everyday. While that may not be a big deal to everyone else, it sure is to them. Some children haven’t left the house in three weeks, and that’s a lot of time for children to be cooped up. Pierce Elementary student, Natasha Zamora says, “I really miss seeing my friends, and I miss science too. My homework is kinda hard, but not too bad.”
COVID-19 Impact Local Government
by Klarissa Norris
COVID-19, coronavirus, has swept across the nation and left a lasting impact on a global and local scale. The global pandemic is affecting local government in many ways.

On March 23, the Chair of the Pierce County Board of Commissioners, Terry J. Wragge declared a state of emergency in Pierce County. He says, “Pierce County is currently threatened from a pandemic outbreak of COVID-19 that is beginning to occur on March 23 and continuing.” State and local governments are on the frontlines of this crisis. That means increased spending on public health and Medicaid. As of March 26, 14 states, including Nebraska, enacted supplemental appropriations or transferred general revenue funds in order to help public health agencies deal with the virus, and many other states are in the process of doing so. These supplemental appropriations and funds are being used in order to cushion the blow on citizens and residents.

Pierce County Economic Development Director Susan Norris commented on the local government’s efforts to obtain government funding by saying, “By declaring Pierce County in a state of emergency we have opened up the county to apply for grants and applications to receive federal funding that is handed down to the state governments by the federal government, that money is then handed down from the state government to the counties. The funding will help assist local businesses and residents recover from the impacts of COVID-19.”

Local government officials have taken action to slow the spread of the virus by following the state-issued Directed Health Measures. These measures put a 10 person limit on public gatherings, require schools to operate without students until May 31, and require restaurants and bars to close their dining areas and move to takeout, delivery, and/or curbside service only.
Coronavirus has impacted local government in many ways and will likely continue to impact local government until a solution to the virus is found.
COVID-19 Effect on Parents
by MacKenzie Peters

The COVID-19 outbreak has affected everyone in the United States and around the world. Students are out of school, employees have been laid off, and businesses have been forced to shut down. One of the age groups most affected by the pandemic include parents.

Not only do parents have to ensure that their children are staying safe, healthy, and educated during these uncertain times, but they also have to play new roles in their children’s lives which would be unnecessary if not for COVID-19.

Schooling has been a major question in many households, as parents must continue to work while their kids stay home. Another concern with parents is what to do with their young ones while away at work. As child care services are closing their doors in order to keep staff and children healthy, parents have nowhere to take their kids throughout the week.

One person fortunate enough to not worry about child care is Lora Schahrer of Norfolk. The mother of two elementary-aged children says, “I’m working from home, while my husband is still working. I’m doing my best to educate my children and establish a schedule or a sense of normalcy that I’ve never had to worry about before. However, it’s not all negative. I get to spend more time with my young children, which is something I have always told myself I would make time to do but struggled with because of the chaos of life. I now get to slow down and enjoy my day, my kids, and the craziness that is my life.”

Besides the stress of maintaining education, some parents are also facing a major financial crisis due to this virus. Many jobs have been lost due to COVID-19. This leaves families wondering when their next paycheck is coming from.

Chris Peters, an elementary teacher and mother of two, speaks on how the pandemic has affected her. “Being a mom of teenagers, I don’t stress too much over their school work. My number one concern is doing the right thing to keep my family safe and healthy. The real challenge is helping them to see the importance of social distancing.”
COVID-19 Impacts Local Government
by Maddie Huber

COVID-19 has impacted a lot of things over the last couple weeks such as schools across the nation shutting their doors to their students for the rest of the year or restaurants having to lay off their employees because their dining areas aren’t open for business due to this virus. But one other thing that COVID-19 has impacted is our local governments.

Since the beginning of March, COVID-19 has been spreading around like wildfire causing our local governments to shut their doors in order to keep their employees safe from this virus. The Pierce County Courthouse has been taking the necessary precautions to keep all their employees safe by closing down certain parts of the courthouse so people can’t come visit. According to Shannon Wragge, the Pierce County Clerk, she said “Right now we are totally locked down, we don’t let anyone in unless they make an appointment and we kindly ask them questions. Court days they are only letting the person that appears in court come in and nobody else can come in, they go in front of the judge and then they leave.”

For example one of those departments that have been closed down would have to be the Department of Motor Vehicles, drivers who need to renew their license can either do it online or thanks to Governor Pete Ricketts the people of Nebraska will have extended time to get their license renewed after the virus has passed.

Another source, Deb Theisen, the Pierce County Clerk Magistrate, said “Well what we did here is when the courthouse first shut down we had one court date already scheduled, and it was too soon to cancel, we had court that day and we had a deputy stand at the door so they could meet them at the door with the schedule to make sure they were on the schedule and only the person who had the actual court date could come in. They would come in, and we would ask them the questions if they had a fever, headache and that and we could only lead no more than 10 in the courtroom at a time. Another way that the offices have been affected is the officers are not writing many tickets, they aren’t stopping people unless it’s something really drastic. So we aren’t really having anything filed, we are getting some mail with civil actions that no one really has to appear on, but we aren’t getting any complaints filed.”
The COVID-19 virus has impacted local governments and so many other things in the United States, but we will be able to come out of this stronger than ever after this virus passes.
Affect on Local Business
by Autumn Hanna

Covid-19 has affected almost everyone’s everyday life. From school being cancelled, to most people not being able to leave their houses at all. These factors have not only majorly affected many large corporations, but also local businesses. One local business that is actually getting more business during these times is Jay’s Place. Employee Alexis Schnoor says, “We’ve actually been busier. We offer delivery now so more people are calling in, and we do not have to do any cash exchange.”

J’s Place, owned by Wanda Backus, has recently started doing deliveries for their food and ice cream. This was an idea Backus had had for a while and decided now was the perfect time to start. Backus said, “The community has been, in my opinion, has been great with continuing to support businesses.” She also said her online ordering has increased, but the lack of people coming in is totally different.
Pierce has always had a strong community, and continues to show that through these hard times.
How is this Virus Affecting Teens?
by: Kailey Marks

In the midst of this chaos, some may be wondering how the COVID-19 or corona virus is affecting local teenagers and what they are doing to fill their days up since school is out. Many, if not all, of the schools, are shut down across the world. Pierce Public Schools closed their doors Monday, March 16, to help stop the increasing spread of the coronavirus.

A major subject that this virus is making a little harder is school. At Pierce High, we have recently switched to doing some online enrichment assignments. This is a big change for students because for almost our whole lives we have sat in classrooms for a span of eight hours a day and now everything has been switched to online classes, online assignments, and seeing our teachers and classmates through computer screens. Although I don’t enjoy going to school sometimes, it kind of hits a little different when that privilege is now gone.

Also, when teenagers aren’t in school, [such as summer or weekends] we like to spend time with our friends. This has also become difficult because we are supposed to stay indoors and away from others to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. I just feel that teenagers, including me, don’t see how real this virus really is, and we just get caught up in “When can I be with my friends again?”

When asked what she has been doing lately, sophomore Brynnlee Marks said, “So far I’ve spent most of my time with family, watching movies, and doing school work.” She also talked about how she misses seeing her friends every day and hanging out with them.

Checking in with junior, Kenzie Moeller, she stated, “I’ve been enjoying it for the most part, but one thing that I truly miss is seeing my friends every day. I've been filling my time with assignments for school, tons of netflix, and working out!”

Also, senior Brett Tinker described how this has impacted his last year of high school and said, “I never thought I’d say I miss school, but I do. It’s not how I wanted my senior year to go, but there’s nothing we can do about it so we just have to live with it for right now.” He went on to say how it gets a little boring trying to find something to stay busy sometimes, but otherwise, he has stayed healthy.
Corona’s Impact on a Local Business
by Madi Hamm

The corona virus has definitely made an impact on everyone but no one has thought about the local businesses and how they have handled it. Owner of local business J’s place, Wanda Backus, had this to say about how her business was affected by the pandemic. “I have had to close my dining which was the biggest part, and I had to limit my seating outside which was more than I was anticipating. I have also had to be very strict on who I can let in the building and how many and that has been a challenge because times can be busy, but they can also be really slow. It has been really up in the air for me.”

Covid-19 hasn’t just affected the restaurants it also affects the other businesses. In speaking to Shanon Davenport at Hardware Hank, she talked about how the virus affected them, saying, “We clean a lot, and we were expecting it to be kinda dead, but we are running constantly and we’re always busy.” Then when asked what is the hardest part about the pandemic, she replied, “Staying healthy and making sure we keep our 6 foot distance, which is hard because people just want to be out.”
This virus has affected everyone and the businesses have been impacted as well. We need to remember to stay safe and stay home so that these businesses can be up and running again.
